text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Bosnia's Moslem-Croat federation Finance Minister Drago Bilandzija, a Croat, issues illegal order allowing tobacco factory in Croat-controlled town of Capljina to sell cigarettes without paying taxes, newspaper alleges.

- Existing symbols of Bosnia, its flag and emblem, will remain the same until something different is agreed by the country's officials, says Mirza Hajric, an adviser to the chairman of collective presidency Alija Izetbegovic.

- Colum Murphy, spokesman for the international High Representative for Bosnia, Carl Bildt, blames Bosnian Serb officials and their counterparts in Moslem-Croat federation for not paying outstanding bills to Russian gas company which supplies the country with gas heating.

- Moslem and Croat officials from divided Bosnian town of Mostar will meet again to try to resolve dispute over forming a joint police force. Earlier, the Croats refused to sign the agreement because they were not satisfied with the proposed insignia, U.N. spokesman Alexander Ivanko says.

- Due to oustanding debt the Russian gas company Gazprom decides to cut supplies to Bosnia to the level which enables only a part of Bosnian Serb republic to use it. The Bosnian gas importer Energoinvest said it will ask for gas supplies to be stopped completely.

- Serb member of collective presidency, Momcilo Krajisnik, sold his house in Sarajevo suburb of Rajlovac for 150,000 German marks, newspaper alleges. The suburb was returned to control of Bosnian government about a year ago. -- Sarajevo newsroom, +387-71-663-864.
